awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Green Algal Tree of Life (GRAToL)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Green Algae Tree of Life (GRAToL) is a project involving the collaboration of five institutions to understand the evolutionary relationships of all of the major groups of green algae, a diverse group of more than 14,000 photosynthetic species worldwide.  Green algae are abundant and play important roles in a wide variety of terrestrial and aquatic habitats, including deserts, extremely salty ponds, and coral reefs, and several species are symbiotic partners with lichens and animals.  Thus, green algae are important primary producers in most ecosystems.  Green algae are diverse in form - from microscopic single cells to large seaweeds - and function as important primary producers in most ecosystems.  The project will employ DNA sequence data to assemble a tree of life reflecting the evolutionary history of the group.  This tree will be critical for an improved classification of known species of algae as well as species that are yet to be discovered.  The project will facilitate further studies of green algae genomics and evolution.

The project will train 3-4 postdoctoral researchers, several graduate students, and numerous undergraduate students in basic research on algae and genomics.  New analytical tools will be developed for use by the broader scientific community.  A public exhibit on the GRAToL will be produced, along with a web site containing images and other information on evolution of the group that will be of interest to educators and the general public.

por.por_cntn:
The project examined the relationships among green algae using a variety of methods, including high-throughput DNA sequencing, computer analysis, light microscopy, and molecular genetics. Green algae are environmentally important, but they are also uniquely important in understanding the biology of land plants including crop and timber plants because of the close relationship between these organisms. We contributed a new database containing over 2.7 million individual protein-coding gene transcripts from 31 different species and used these data to identify genes useful for phylogenetic study and to better understand the biology of these vital organisms. With a dataset of over 1600 orthologs (<10% missing sequences) we are identifying and isolating disparate evolutionary signals, and reconstructing deep phylogenetic relationships with unprecedented confidence. Transcriptome wide comparative analyses are revealing broad scale patterns of gene content evolution and implicating recurrent whole genome duplications in major evolutionary transitions. Detailed analyses of key molecular genetic mechanisms are providing insights into the origins and evolution of: developmental regulation of three-dimensional growth, plant hormones, photorespiration, and desiccation tolerance. One of our most significant findings was the demonstration that the green alga Spirogyra has a functional system making use of a key plant hormone, ethylene. This is already providing new insights into how crop plants respond to stress and interact with the environment.
